column4: I set up a samba file server on a P3 500MHz 256MB box and sometimes I am under the impression that the transfer speed between server and other machines could be faster if the box was better. Is it just an illusion or is my box a discernable bottleneck ?
the only thing that will be slowing you down is potentially your disc subsystem.
On the hardware you describe it's probably some old slow PATA setup.
what do you mean by 'disc subsystem' ?
oh yes it is !
Basically, you should verify that you have at least DMA support for your IDE controller/disc.
so it's not the cpu itself, it's the PATA
hdparm should tell you tht.
IDE/ATA comes in a number of levels of "hellness".
less is better ?
well, run hdparm -d /dev/hda <= that will tell if your hardware at least uses DMA.
all right, one second
and you should probably check first the docs if hdparm -d does not destroy your hardware :-P (no it does not, but sometimes there are joksters around :-p)
whats the command used to bring up connected drives ?

I remember once when a colleague and me were quite irritated by the "root" at a customers installation, and while waiting for the email round trip painted out ways to make that stupid MSCE execute rm -Rf without us being implicated by the email.
connected drives?
well I want to list the drives that buntu sees
/dev/sdb5, thats all I get returned
I am thinking rm -R isn't a nice thing to do :P
so any ideas on what to do when the output I got it /dev/sdb5:
What output? Beside you should probably be running it on /dev/sdb :-P
*shucks* hdparm does not know about DMA on SCSI devices :(

well thanks anyways then ! even with DMA, I am pretty sure that the combination of 550MHz along with PATA connection as well as the fact that it's streaming over a cheap 40$ D-link router helps the slow speed
